Legal_Issue: Was the Visa Officer's decision to deny the Applicant's H&C application reasonable and procedurally fair?
Governing_Law: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: The Officer failed to adequately analyze the best interests of the Applicant's grandchildren, particularly Alexsey's serious health condition.
Decision_Outcome: The decision was unreasonable and breached process.
Legal_Rule: Section 25(1) requires consideration of the best interests of children affected by immigration decisions. Decisions must be reasonable and follow procedural fairness.
Procedural_Issue: Extrinsic evidence was used without giving the Applicant a chance to respond.
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient consideration of the best interests of children and procedural unfairness
Outcome_on_Merits: The original decision was set aside
Judicial_Review_Outcome: The matter is referred back for re-determination by a different visa officer.
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Breach of procedural fairness due to use of extrinsic evidence without opportunity to respond
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged denial of H&C application based on inadequate consideration of children's best interests and procedural unfairness
Court_Result: Decision set aside; case remanded for reconsideration
Legal_Rule_Source: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 25(1)
Remedy_Sought: Allowance of H&C application or reassessment by a different officer
Legal_Provision: Section 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Authority: Federal Court (implied from judicial review context)
Governing_Rule: Section 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
